awd_titl_txt: DNA deformability in linear and circular DNA: Implications for site-specific recognition
awd_abstract_narration:
Sequence-dependent DNA shape, and level of flexibility, is at the core of how DNA binding proteins recognize their binding sites. Protein binding to DNA is important for many aspects of DNA function as a means for storing and transmitting information in a cell.  DNA flexibility is studied using both computational and experimental methods, but experimental studies testing computational predictions have lagged, leaving a big gap in our understanding.  This study will provide an experimental dataset that will significantly expand our understanding of one type of DNA deformability, contributing to the overall efforts by the DNA mechanics community to rationally predict and map sequence-dependent DNA conformations and deformations. Specifically, the research targets sequence patterns that render DNA highly kinkable, leading to improved rules for recognizing such sites and their protein binding partners. As participants in the research activities, undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in a cross-disciplinary research environment. The PI will contribute to curriculum revisions leading to more quantitative skills for life science majors, and will develop biophysics-related lab activities to be integrated into the curriculum for physics majors. These efforts, together with biophysics courses the PI previously developed, will be integrated into a planned Biophysics major at the PI's institution. Longer range goals are to develop an interdisciplinary graduate program in Molecular and Cellular Biophysics. The PI will work with high school teachers to develop teaching modules at the growing interface between physics and biology, and host high school students in her lab in the summer. The PI will also mentor, through summer research activities, underrepresented students recruited through an outreach program at the PI's institution. 

This study brings together multifaceted approaches to elucidate the rules that govern DNA sequence-dependent shape and deformability, and to examine how these variations in DNA flexibility influence protein binding. This study will identify highly deformable DNA sequences using in vitro selection of random sequences that bind with high affinity to architectural IHF/HU family of DNA bending proteins that severely kink DNA at two sites. The sequence patterns that enable this high degree of kinking will be important for developing models of sequence-dependent DNA deformability that go well beyond the small base-step deformations described by harmonic potentials. The intrinsic DNA deformability of selected sequences will be investigated using laser temperature-jump spectroscopy, biochemical assays, NMR-probed base pair dynamics, and computational modeling of bending deformations. The researchers will (1) examine the correlation between protein-binding affinities and DNA deformation energies; (2) investigate how the variations in the binding affinities are reflected in the DNA-bending rates to form the complex; and (3) examine the potential for spontaneous bending/kinking of these DNA substrates by (i) measuring base-pair dynamics at kink sites using NMR approaches; (ii) probing their reactivity within the context of minicircles by biochemically detecting kinks and unpaired bases induced by severe bending; (iii) modeling structural dynamics of highly deformable sequences. This study will generate a comprehensive dataset of sequence patterns that underpin DNA dynamics and flexibility. Results from this project will be made available on the website http://ansari.lab.uic.edu/research/ .

por.por_cntn:
DNA-binding proteins that perform essential cellular functions bend or twist the DNA, often sharply kinking the DNA at their specific binding sites. Such "site-specific" recognition relies on the ease with which DNA can be deformed, especially for proteins that cannot directly "read" the sequence at that site and, instead, use "indirect readout" to sense sequence-dependent DNA shape/deformability. The rules governing local DNA deformability remain largely untested, especially for severe DNA deformations. This study aimed to expand our understanding of DNA deformability and augment ongoing efforts to rationally predict sequence-dependent DNA conformations and deformations.

The goal was to uncover sequence patterns that render the DNA highly "kinkable". High-throughput "SELEX" studies were performed to identify high-affinity DNA sequences for proteins that sharply kink DNA. Two related prokaryotic, nucleoid-associated proteins were used: Integration Host Factor (IHF) from Escherichia coli and Hbb from Borrelia burgdorferi, a spirochete that causes Lyme disease. These proteins help form multi-component nucleoprotein complexes for various cellular processes. They have a remarkable ability to bend certain DNA sites into a sharp "U-turn" over ~35 base pairs (bp) by inducing two ~90-degree kinks in DNA. This project aimed to identify and characterize DNA sequences that bind with high affinity to IHF/Hbb, presumably because they are more readily kinked by these proteins; to examine the intrinsic "kinkability" of these DNA sequences; and to provide a database for further development and validation of models that characterize DNA mechanical properties.

The SELEX DNA library, based on an IHF binding site, contained a 6-bp region at one of the protein-induced kink sites that was randomized, resulting in a library with 46 = 4,096 unique sequences, which were ranked by their binding affinities to IHF/Hbb. The sequences -- high affinity "winners" or low-affinity "losers" -- were analyzed for their sequence composition, their intrinsic shape preferences, and the energetic cost for distorting each sequence into the U-turn shape, from elastic models for DNA deformations. A few results stand out: (1) Runs of 3 or more As in a row ("A-tracts") at or near the randomized kink site were prevalent among the losers, indicating that they inhibit kinking; (2) winning sequences were predicted to adopt pre-distorted shapes at the kink sites; (3) elastic modeling revealed a weak correlation between binding affinity and ease of deformability. These studies added to previously known unique properties of A-tracts that make them highly important sequence elements for genetic regulation. They also underscored the limitations of elastic models for describing sharply kinked DNA, likely due to an excessive energy penalty for ~90-degree DNA bends. Altogether, these studies laid a foundation for systematically and quantitatively approaching questions surrounding DNA of high deformability and generated a comprehensive dataset of sequence patterns that underpin DNA flexibility. The results from these studies can be used to improve current models of DNA mechanics.

These studies also provided insights into conformational fluctuations in IHF-DNA complexes in solution that crystal structures don't reveal. Fluorescence-based measurements revealed a surprisingly dynamic complex whose conformational flexibility was further modulated by sequence variations. An A-tract on one side of the U-turn bend was found to be critical in holding that side of the DNA against the protein: In variant complexes lacking the A-tract, that side becomes "flappy". Notably, the different dynamics of these complexes reflect their different roles in their natural context, the complex that integrates lambda-phage into the E. coli chromosome during viral infection.  Thus, this study provided fresh insights into the finely tuned IHF-DNA interactions in its biological role of facilitating the formation of many different higher-order protein-DNA complexes. 

We also examined whether intrinsic DNA flexibility/dynamics impact how DNA-damage-recognition proteins pinpoint rare damage against a vast excess of undamaged genomic DNA. We discovered that DNA constructs with 3-bp mismatches that are specifically recognized in vitro by eukaryotic nucleotide excision repair protein Rad4 exhibit large amplitude intrinsic fluctuations that Rad4 likely senses when searching for DNA damage.  Rad4-bound complexes in solution were also found to be much more heterogeneous and dynamic than could be deduced from crystal structures; such conformational fluctuations could facilitate recruitment of additional DNA-repair proteins.

PI Ansari led a faculty-student team in redesigning and modernizing their introductory course-sequence "Physics for Life Sciences", with addition of molecular biophysics topics, biophysics-based laboratory activities, and active group learning sessions. The PI was instrumental in modernizing the UIC Physics PhD curriculum that will include new courses that cover biological physics topics, thus significantly enhancing the graduate training for students in interdisciplinary fields. The PI also hosted summer students from Chicago public high schools with a significant fraction of underserved students. Co-PI Rice served in several diversity-related activities: as departmental diversity representative; on her Division's Diversity Committee; as a co-director for a Summer Research Program for incoming, particularly underrepresented, graduate students; and as a poster judge and panelist at the local annual SACNAS meeting.
